editionStmt.funder: Conversion of the printed catalogue to TEI funded by the Thompson Family Charitable Trust

supportDesc.support: all on vellum (all FSOS/FHHF, except MSS 4 and 7–8, HSOS/HFFH).

binding.p: Brown leather over bookboard, s. xvi, with a blind-stamped border, partly restored in the upper corner, perhaps suggesting a chain fitting removed. The rolls are Oldham MW.d (10) (no. 872, plate LI), used alone by an Oxford binder 1560–1613. Sewn on four thongs. Gold ‘188’ at the head of the spine, very indistinct in black ink on the leading edges. All three edges reddened. Pastedowns old vellum, a College bookplate on the front pastedown. At the front, three vellum flyleaves from manuscript (the first has been used as a pastedown in an earlier binding, and the second and third are a bifolium); at the rear, a single vellum flyleaf from manuscript (iv).

origin.origDate: s. xiii med.–xiv in., s. xv med

history.provenance: ‘Carrius me possidet’ (fol. 114, upper margin, s. xv/xvi) and ‘Christoferus Carieus 20 Aug Cxo’ (partly cut off, fol. 114v, the first inscription repeated below in italic, s. xvi ex.); the same italic hand has added other pen-trials, and there are accounts for May and June of an unspecified year (s. xvi). For discussion, see Andrew G. Watson, ‘Christopher and William Carye, Collectors of Monastic Manuscripts, and “John Carye”, The Library 5th ser. 20 (1965), 135–42 at 136–7, 142.
‘Nicolai Lynneby Ioann Oxon’ (fol. 1, upper margin; and fol. 24).
history.acquisition: ‘Liber Collegij Sanctj Joannis Baptistae Oxon’ ex dono Nicolaj Linnebye socij 1605’ (fol. iiiv).

source.bibl: Ralph Hanna, A descriptive catalogue of the western medieval manuscripts of St. John's College, Oxford (Oxford: Oxford University Press, 2002)

availability.p: For enquiries relating to this manuscript please contact St John's College Library.

Thorndike, Lynn, and Pearl Kibre, A Catalogue of Incipits of Medieval Scientific Writings in Latin, 2nd edn. (Cambridge, Mass., 1963).

van Waesberghe, Jos. Smits (ed.), Guidonis Aretini, Micrologus, Corpus scriptorum de musica 4 (1955).
Walther, Hans, Initia carminum ac versuum Medii Aevi posterioris Latinorum, 2nd edn (Göttingen, 1969).
Watson, Andrew G., ‘Christopher and William Carye, Collectors of Monastic Manuscripts, and “John Carye”, The Library 5th ser. 20 (1965), 135–42.
Wordsworth, Charles, The Ancient Kalendar of the University of Oxford, Oxford Historical Society 45 (1903–4), 33–8, 230–43.

msItem.note: the contents leaf from a legal MS, mounted upside down. The recto gives chapters from a text: ‘Capitulum primum Quod sancta Ecclesia libera sit Capitulum secundum De heredibus per seruit’ militar’ tenentibus Capitulum tercium De modo eorundem faciendi homagia’. The verso starts with statutes, running from Magna carta to Winchester, then has the standard tracts: Curia baronis, both Henghams, Cadit assisa,… de Bastarda, ends with Assizes of Bread and Beer, Fet aseuer, and the Register of Writs. s. xiii/xiv with some added notes, mounted upside down.
drawings of faces and notes

two sets of verses ‘Gnosia fecisset inopem sapienter amassos’ and ‘Si potes et ceras remoue quam ymagine muta’ (OVID, Remedia amoris, 745–9, 723–34, the latter written in the same hand as the material on fol. 114). A diagram of concentric circles between the two sets of verses.

msItem.incipit: Nota quod libra est nomen generale instrumenti siue brachia sunt equalia siue non set equilibris est libra brachiorum
msItem.explicit: set huiusmodi diuisio usque ad vnitatem procedere ?uori permittitur ut 12. 20. 24or. etc
msItem.note: In the hand of fols. 40 (in the same double column format with red paraphs) and 107v.
a diagram of the eye, its parts, and their connection to the brain (?).
apparently from a legal text, anglicana s. xiii/xiv.

msItem.incipit: Omnia que a primeua rerum originem processerunt scilicet in eo ratione numerorum
msItem.explicit: de radicum extractione sufficiant tam in numeris quadratis quam cubicis
msItem.author: JOHANNES DE SACRO BOSCO
msItem.title: Algorismus
msItem.note: (Sharpe, no. 865 [306]) (TK 1295), ed. Maximilian Curtze, Petri Philomeni de Dacia in Algorismum vulgarem Johannis de Sacrabosco Commentarius (Copenhagen, 1897), 1-19.

msItem.incipit: Si contingat quod compotum iactare debes dicitur de receptis uel expenditis sic est agendum
msItem.explicit: nullo loco adenare usque adhuc uacuo remanente

msItem.incipit: Tractatum de spera 4. capitulis distinguimus dicentes primo quid sit spera Spera igitur ab euclidi sic describitur Spera est transitus circumferencie dimidii circuli
msItem.explicit: passione domini dixisse Aut deus nature patitur aut mundana machina dissoluetur
msItem.author: SACROBOSCO
msItem.title: Tractatus de Sphaera
msItem.note: ed. Lynn Thorndike, The Sphere of Sacrobosco and Its Commentators (Chicago, 1949), 76-117.

msItem.incipit: Cum sapiencia sit magis inclita multiplicata │ Distribuentem reddit habentem spernit auarum
msItem.note: Six verses (not in Walther).

msItem.incipit: De tonorum agnitionibus et singularum differentiarum secundum uarias incepciones compendiosam doctrinam propalare
msItem.explicit: continet minorem totum et insuper eius decimam octaua exceptam 27. uersus
msItem.note: Fols. 15–16v are blank but ruled.

layoutDesc.layout:
In double columns, each column
125 38 , with 8 mm between columns, in 44 lines. Prickings; bounded and ruled in brown ink.

handDesc.handNote: Written in a small gothic textura quadrata of a university type, s. xiii2. Punctuation by point and punctus elevatus.

decoDesc.decoNote: Texts headed by 2-or 3-line blue lombards on red flourishing; within texts, similar capitals alternate with red ones on blue flourishing, and red paraphs are used to break the texts.

msItem.incipit: Hec algorismus ars presens dicitur in qua │Talibus indorum fruimur bis quinque figuris
msItem.explicit: sint pone sub una A dextris digitum seruando prius documentum
msItem.author: ALEXANDER DE VILLA DEI
msItem.title: Algorismus
msItem.note: (Walther, no. 7470, listing 58 copies), ed. James Orchard Halliwell, Rara mathematica (London, 1839), 73–83.

msItem.incipit: Si sit continua progressis terminus impar │ Per maius medium totalem
msItem.explicit: esse numeros unum tria v.que │ Et duo bis duo sex dicas tibi quatuor esse
msItem.note: Three sets of further mathematical verses (Walther, no. 17974, where they are tentatively viewed as a continuation of item 6).

msItem.incipit: Formant fungonem feriatia gramata vii. │ alpha betha duo
msItem.explicit: Hec eadem parua debet concordia queri │ Qua mediante potest quod queris semper haberi
msItem.note: Verses on the use of calendar tables (Walther, no. 6774), citing seven copies, two in Cambridge, Gonville and Caius College MS 136. A concluding line added later: ‘Vt uideas quantum bisexti distet ab anno’. Fols. 19vb–20rb are blank.

msItem.incipit: Fallit amor cautos errant graue basia dantes │ Cultor erit gradus vnde degens fiat amatus
msItem.explicit: Terminus hinc unus benedictus inde Matheus │ Solsticium cristum decimum tenet atque iohannem
msItem.note: Walther, no. 6236, also in CUL, MS Mm.iv.41, fol. 105. Fols. 21rb–23v are blank; fol. 22 is ruled.

layoutDesc.layout:
In double columns, each column
126 46–8 , with 7 mm between columns, in 45 lines to the column. Prickings; bounded and ruled in black ink.

handDesc.handNote: Written in gothic textura semiquadrata, s. xiii2, perhaps a continuation of the previous MS, very similar in page format, although the hand differs. Punctuation by point at the line ends.

decoDesc.decoNote: Headings in red, red-slashed capitals at the head of each line.

msItem.rubric: IOHANNIS DE SACRO BOSCO noua compoti incipit compilacio
msItem.incipit: Compotus est sciencia considerans tempora ex solis et lune motibus
msItem.explicit: septimane erunt in tempore quesito Ne tamen quandoque fallant caueat sibi calculator
msItem.author: JOHANNES DE SACRO BOSCO
msItem.title: De anni ratione
msItem.note: Sharpe, no. 865 (306), ed. Libellus de anni ratione seu ut uocatur uulgo Computus Ecclesiasticus (Paris, 1550), fols. 5-53. Preceded by ‘Versus contra inuidos Inuide quid laceras prosunt que carmina cunctis ’ (Walther, no. 9540, four lines). In describing this MS, I have not cited readings from the glosses.

msItem.rubric: Ad inueniendum dies egiptiacos in ianuario
msItem.incipit: Augo docens adam kalo cingens kapo nekam │ Abbas ceka cekas eccen
msItem.explicit: Mobilis ibo cifos modo liber habeto coenos

msItem.incipit: Si esset centrum solaris circuli in medio celi essent solsticia in principio cancri et capricorni
msItem.explicit: equinoccio et tunc respondebit eleuationi solis astrolabium circa meridiem Explicit
msItem.note: TK 1448, also in CUL, MS Kk.i.1, fol. 105rv. Fol. 40vb is blank.

layoutDesc.layout: Item 10 in double columns, each column 125 38 , with 8 mm between columns, in 44 lines to the page. Prickings; bounded and ruled in black ink.
Item 11 writing area 125 65 . In long lines, 15–21 lines to the page, with variable spacing for an interlinear gloss. No prickings; bounded in brown ink, no rules.
Item 12 in double columns, each column 125 38 , with 9 mm between columns, in 45 lines to the column. No prickings; bounded in lead, no rules.

handDesc.handNote: Item 10 written in gothic textura semiquadrata, s. xiii med. or xiii2, with extensive glosses in a tiny hand of s. xiii ex. (a few in a hand of early s. xv?). Punctuation by point and punctus elevatus.
Item 11 written in another gothic textura, s. xiii med.
Item 12 written in gothic textura semiquadrata, which resembles the late glossing hand of text 8 (possibly s. xv).

decoDesc.decoNote: In text 10, headings in red, many unfilled.
Alternate red and blue lombards on flourishing of the other colour, 4-line at the incipit, 2-line for internal divisions.
The text divided by red paraphs.
Frequent diagrams in red, green, and black, one illustration (fol. 28ra) of the ‘serpent of the year’.
In text 11, a heading in red, red-slashed capitals at line-openings, a few of the glosses in red.

origin.origDate: s. xiii ex. and early s. xv? (additions to item 10)

msItem.incipit: Hec tabula prima tabula terminorum dicitur quoniam in illa termini festorum mobilium per ordinem inueniuntur
msItem.explicit: Vera autem coniunctio est cum corpus unius fuerit sub corpore alterius
msItem.title: ‘Exposicio calendarii’ (so TK 607).
msItem.note: Followed (fols. 42–9v) by the tables and a calendar (fols. 44ff), the latter with Oxford additions, s. xv (14 January noted as the start of Hilary Term, 12 February as the ‘translatio sancte fredeswyde’ and 15 May her invention). Ed., in part, John R. Magrath, The Obituary Book of Queen’s College Oxford, Oxford Historical Society 56 (1910), 121–6; see the further discussion in Charles Wordsworth, The Ancient Kalendar of the University of Oxford, Oxford Historical Society 45 (1903–4), 33–8, 230–43. Since the author of these additions identifies 20 October with ‘Dedicatio colegij marie magdalene’, he has been taken to be attached to that college. Fol. 50rv is blank.

layoutDesc.layout:
In double columns, each column
128 38 , with 8 mm between columns, in 44 lines to the page. No prickings; the text bounded and ruled in lead, the tables and calendar in red ink.

handDesc.handNote: Written in another contemporary textura, with later additions in the calendar.

decoDesc.decoNote: Red arabesque capitals at textual divisions, red paraphs for subsidiary units.
The table and calendar in red and green inks, entries headed by 1-line red, blue, and green lombards.

msItem.incipit: Si fuerit canonium simmetrum magnitudine et substancie eiusdem diuidaturque in duas partes
msItem.explicit:
[fol. 52v] et uirtute propor
cio una erunt eiusdem generis
msItem.title: ‘Liber de canonio’ (so TK 1449)
msItem.note: ed. Ernest A. Moody and Marshall Clagett, The Medieval Science of Weights (Madison, Wis., 1952), 64–74, where our copy is unnoted (and not very similar). A text on balances, with a gloss; only two text and three gloss lines on fol. 53, the verso probably originally blank.

[an added text?]: a table for equivalent measures, ‘Nomina Minutiarum Quot vncias habet etc.’, with verbal explanation of equivalents at the foot: ‘Denarius stater et siclus unum et idem sunt Denarius enim constat ex 10 nummis Stater ex 20 obulis ’

msItem.incipit: Omnis ponderosi motum esse ad medium quod grauisuus est uelocius descendere
msItem.explicit: sit a centro differencia secundum hunc situm eque grauia fient
msItem.author: JORDANUS
msItem.title: Elementa super demonstrationem ponderum
msItem.note: (TK 1000) ed. Moody and Clagett, 128–32, breaking off at line 102. Again with a gloss. Fols. 55v–7v are blank.

layoutDesc.layout: Writing area 128 78 , with a 35 mm leading-edge column for diagrams. Written in long lines, about 27 text lines to the page, the gloss line half that of the text. No prickings; bounded and ruled in brown crayon.

handDesc.handNote: Each of the three texts in a different hand: two are gothic texturas, quadrata and semiquadrata respectively, the third an anglicana-tinged textura of s. xiii/xiv. Punctuation by point and occasional punctus elevatus in both text and gloss.

msItem.incipit: Intentio huius auctoris est tractare de 7. discriminibus uocum ypallage et de 7. discretis uocibus ostendendo quomodo musice uoces
msItem.explicit: Contus Miter Curuus Virga Claudicans Ascendens Pes Abusi he sunt
msItem.note: A commentary on GUIDO OF AREZZO, Micrologus (TK 760), presented as an introduction to item 18. Fols. 60v–1v are blank, fol. 60v partly ruled, but in a format resembling that of MS 5.

layoutDesc.layout:
In double columns, each column
125 46 , with 9 mm between columns, in 51 lines to the column. Fragmentary prickings; bounded and ruled in brown crayon.

handDesc.handNote: Written in gothic textura semiquadrata, s. xiii2. Punctuation by point and occasional punctus elevatus.

msItem.incipit: Musica dicitur a potu myson id est a querendo quia primitus
msItem.rubric: Incipit micrologus sermo GUYDONIS in musica
msItem.incipit: Gymnasio musas placuit reuocare solutas Ut pateant paruis habite uix

[fol. 62v] Diuini timoris tociusque prudencie fulgore clarissimo dulcissimo patri et reuerentissimo domino Theodaldo GUIDO suorum monachorum utinam minimus quicquid seruus et filius Cum solitarie uite saltim modicam exequi cupiam quantitatem nostre benignitas dignatio
Igitur qui nostram disciplinam petit aliquantos cantus nostris descriptos addiscat
msItem.explicit: ipso doctore semper humanas tenebras ilustrante cuius summa sapiencia per cuncta uiget secula Amen
msItem.author: GUIDO OF AREZZO
msItem.title: Micrologus
msItem.note: ed. Jos. Smits van Waesberghe, Corpus scriptorum de musica 4 (1955) 79–233, with a description of our MS at 44-6. A chapter table appears between the letter and the text.

msItem.incipit: Musicam disciplinam non esse contempnendam multa et antiquorum gentilium uidelicet et sanctorum
msItem.explicit: et rursus alii huiusmodi dispositio quorum extremi tripli
msItem.author: AURELIANUS monachus REOMENSIS
msItem.title: 'Musicae disciplina’
msItem.note: (TK 898), chs. 1–2 only, ed. Martin Gerbert, Scriptores ecclesiastici de musica, 3 vols. (St Blasien, 1784; rept. [Milan, 1931]), 1:29–32.

msItem.incipit: Gliscunt corda meis hominum mollita camenis │ Vna mihi uirtus numeratos Musicorum ut cantorum magna est distancia Isti dicunt illi sciunt que componat carmina
msItem.explicit: Defert alterius cum suscipit altera uires Inde duo signum uariant loca cuius ad ipsum
msItem.author: GUIDO
msItem.title: Regulae rhythmicae

msItem.incipit: Temporibus nostris super omnes homines fatui sunt cantores In omni enim arte ualde plura sunt que
msItem.explicit: Facili coloquio in ipsa neumarum figura monstratur si sicut debent ex industria componantur
msItem.author: GUIDO
msItem.title: ‘Praefatio in antiphonarium’

msItem.incipit: Beatissimo atque dilectissimo fratri M W per amfractus multos deiectus et actus aut dura sunt tempora aut diuine dispositionis obscura discrimina
msItem.explicit: cuius liber non cantonbus sed solis philosophis utilis est
msItem.author: GUIDO
msItem.title: Regule de ignotu cantu or ‘Epistola Michaeli monacho’,

msItem.incipit: Omnes autenti quinto loco a se principia seu fines distinctionum mittunt venturus uero sexto
msItem.explicit: venturus uero autenticus usque ad suppositum semitonium et tritus deponitur
msItem.incipit: Dyapason quid est Dyapason est quelibet uox grauis cum acuta resonant unice
msItem.explicit: unam eademque principio et fine disiunctionum partium sillabarumque disiungit
msItem.note: Two brief tracts, separated from the preceding one by only a painted initial; they also occur together in Cambridge, Trinity College MS R.15.22, fol. 138rv.

msItem.incipit: Primum querite regnum dei [marked interlinearly with letters as notes] Ob indicium primi toni hec antiphona ponitur
msItem.explicit: quam iudice aut intimorum auribus tecum amabiliter queso conlatura commitas
msItem.note: According to van Waesberghe, in part a discussion of the score printed in E. de Coussemaker, Scriptorum de Musica Medii Aevi Novum Seriem 2 (Paris, 1867), 87. See further Michel Huglo, Les Tonaires: Inventaire, analyse, comparison (Paris, 1971), 192.

msItem.incipit: Fistulam longissimam quante longitudinis latitudinis ne uelut facito ita tamen ut omnia mediocriter fiant
msItem.explicit: easdem fistulas a prioribus ita ut secundum dyapason a prirno mensus est
msItem.title: ‘Mensura fistulam’
msItem.note: the text also appears in Trinity R.15.22, fols. 126–8.

msItem.incipit: Quicumque cimbala uult facere recte consonantia ad cantandum ad unumquodque debet ceram diuidere
msItem.explicit: nichilque deesse dyateisaron et vyapente atque dyapason
msItem.title: ‘Mensura cymbalarum’
msItem.note: ed. van Waesberghe, Cymbala (Bells in the Middle Ages), Studies and Documents 1 (Rome, 1951), 54–5, also using the copy in Trinity R.15.22, fol. 131rv.

msItem.incipit: Ut dabis nunc rationem quare per alias uero uel discrepantes sint uel adeo
msItem.explicit: fiunt 22. ad 33. 3. et sic infinitum horum descriptio quo dicuntur
msItem.note: Identified by van Waesberghe as excerpts from a commentary on HUCBALD monachus ELNONENSIS, Musica Enchirialis, the text ed. Gerbert, 1:192–4.

msItem.incipit: De natura modorum pauca aperiamus Primus uero modus finem suum
msItem.explicit: propter semitonium Octauus in F et G a b c Hec tibi dicta placent formis si sedulus absis
msItem.note: Fol. 96v was originally blank.
Added text:

msItem.rubric: Hec sunt de disciplinis et sapiencijs PTOLOMEI
msItem.incipit: Conueniens est intelligenti pro deo vercundari cum ea que non sunt grata cogitate
msItem.explicit: Anima ignorans socio suo magis inimicatur
msItem.finalRubric: hec in prohemmio almagesti sapientis PTHOLOMEI
msItem.note: Proverbs from the Almagest (TK 263 cite the same incipit from Munich, Bayerische Staatsbibliothek, MS CLM 9683, fols. 62ra–5rb). In anglicana, s. xv med. or xv3/4, the same hand which wrote item 32 (fols. 109–10v).

layoutDesc.layout: Writing area 130 74 , a central text column between two gloss columns, the inner column 21 mm wide, the leading-edge one 32 mm wide. In 26 long lines to the page (the text; 51 lines for the gloss). Bounded and ruled in black ink.

handDesc.handNote: Written in textura semiquadrata, s. xiii med.

decoDesc.decoNote: Two- to 4-line alternate blue and red lombards on flourishing of the other colour (some flourishing not completed), frequent 1-line in-text lombards to break the texts.
Headings in red, but most blanks unfilled (all after fol. 72v).

msItem.incipit: Cvm uolueris scire in quo signo sit sol et quot gradus perambulauerit ex eo
msItem.explicit: pone gradum solis super lineam emisperii occidentalis et fac sicut predictum est
msItem.author: MESSAHALA
msItem.title: Practica astrolabii
msItem.note: (TK 356), ed. R. T. Gunther, Chaucer and Messahalla on the Astrolabe (Oxford, 1929), 217–31. The remainder of the column filled with notes added s. xiv in., and the verso originally blank, now filled with a table of stellar angles and with angles for a variety of locales, including Oxford, London, Canterbury added s. xiv1.

msItem.incipit: Cum uolueris hec scire accipe altitudinem et constue constitue 12. domos deinde aspice
msItem.explicit: scitur quantum transitur de annis cristi ex annis arabii si deus uoluerit
msItem.note: A further series of astronomical operations; a later s. xiv hand has numbered fols. 97–101va as 30 chapters, the succeeding section numbered ‘31 et 1’. The text may break here, or extend to fol. 102ra: ‘Capitulum 31 in scienti altitudinis turrium et celorum talium que eleuantur—ipsum et radicem rei et quod exierit erit longitudo inter utrasque’.

msItem.rubric: Incipiunt sentencie de diuersis libris excepte in quibus exponuntur equationes multe dubitaciones [these two words marked for transposition]
msItem.incipit: Qui ad astronomie scienciam desiderat peruenire Quicumque ad eius dulcedinem cupit pertingere
msItem.explicit: finitus fuerit numerus tuus in eodem intrabit mensis quam uolueris si deus voluerit
msItem.author: JOHN ‘HISPANUS’
msItem.title: 'Scientia annorum Arabum et de annis domini’
msItem.note: (TK 1203), ed. J. Millas i Vallicrosa, ‘Una obra desconocida de Johannes Avendaut Hispanus’, Osiris 1 (1936), 451–75 at 459–62 only, collating our MS against the copy in Madrid, Biblioteca nacionale MS 10053. On the author, see Charles S. F. Burnett, ‘Magister Johannes Hispanus: Towards the Identity of a Toledan Translator’, in Comprendre et maîtrisier la nature au moyen âge (Geneva, 1994), 425–36, this text mentioned at 429. Nearly all of fol. 103v and all of fol. 104 were originally blank, now filled with astronomical notes, in anglicana s. xiv1, probably by the hand responsible for the chapter numeration in item 30. The text is followed by two further added notes, one by the hand of fols. 103v–4, at the foot of the page.

layoutDesc.layout:
In double columns, each column
140 38–42 , with 5 mm between columns, in 51 lines to the column (ample margins left for glosses). No prickings; bounded and ruled in brown crayon.

handDesc.handNote: Written in gothic textura semiquadrata, s. xiv in. Punctuation by point, medial point, and punctus elevatus.

decoDesc.decoNote: Blanks for capitals unfilled and no headings; diagrams in text ink.

p.note: Probably comprised of binding materials, with no main text items, but a series of medical and astronomical notes. Fols. 105, 107, and 108 are blank (fol. 107 has two pen-trials). On fol. 108v a fragment of a booklist, s. xiii ex., comprised mostly of scientific and classical texts (a few with incipits cited), inc. ‘ Macbiu Macrobium Cum in Affrica venit │ Gondisalmi de anima Cum omnes homines │ Timeum platonis Socrates │ Seneca de moribus et de paupertate │ vque epistolas dindimi et Alexandri Sepius ad aures ’

msItem.incipit: Algorismum proporcionum presul Meldensis phillipe quod pictagoram dicerem si fas esset credere sentenciam eius de riditu animarum Vna medietas sic scribitur 1/2 vna 3a sic 1/3 et due tercie sic
msItem.explicit: residuum que quidem remaneret subtrahendo totum a toto et hoc est facile
msItem.author: NICOLE ORESME
msItem.title: Algorismum proporcionum
msItem.note: (TK 80, 506, 1596), breaking off after the eighth rule of the first tract, ed. E. L. W. M. Curtze (Berlin, 1868), pp. 13–18 (the edition lacks the brief prologue). The remainder was originally blank, now with added notes: fol. 113v on astronomy; fol. 114 excerpts from OVID ‘libro primo sine titulo’, inc. ‘Militat omnis amans et habet sua castra cupido’ [Amores 1.9.1, some further excerpts from book 2]; one bit added in another hand ‘Est qui nequiciam locus exigat omnibus illum │ Deliciis imple sit procul inde pudor ’ [Amores 3.14.17]. Fol. 114 was a pastedown in an earlier binding.

layoutDesc.layout: In long lines, 42 lines to the page. No prickings; bounded in brown crayon but unruled.

handDesc.handNote: Written in anglicana, s. xv med., the same hand which added item (g) on fol. 96v. Punctuation by occasional point.

decoDesc.decoNote: Blanks for capitals unfilled; a red lombard and a red paraph in the first paragraph.
